STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
January 26, 2024
Delora O’Neill
WELLSPRING LUTHERAN SERVICES GAYLORD
1260 S OTSEGO AVE,
GAYLORD, MI, 49735-9587
Re: License #: CB690358779
Dear Ms. O’Neill:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
January 12, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, Area Manager, at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Doug Turrill, Licensing Consultant
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement
• (2) The agreement must be signed and dated
by the youth and the social service worker.
The agreement must be reviewed with the
youth at least once every 90 calendar days and
a copy provided to the youth.
One independent living file was reviewed. One of one did not document that the
independent living agreement was reviewed with the youth every 90 days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
02/03/22 INTERIM, CAP approved 03/15/22
12/16/22 RENEWAL, CAP approved 01/04/23
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every
90 calendar days thereafter.
2

Six foster care files were reviewed. One of six did not have a USP documented in
the file.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
12/16/22 RENEWAL, CAP approved 01/04/23
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Opening (ISP) Within 30 calendar days before
or 14 calendar days after case opening. Case Plan
Reassessment (USP) Within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is used to
capture family demographics, FTM logistical
information, needs, strengths, action steps, safety
concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM.
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
Six foster care files were reviewed. One of six files did not document that a case
reassessment FTM had been completed for the service plan period.
One of six files did not document that the DHS-1105 had been completed for the
FTM.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
02/03/22 INTERIM, CAP approved 03/15/22
12/16/22 RENEWAL, CAP approved 01/04/23
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
• Caseworker. • Supervisor. • Second line supervisor,
when siblings in care are placed apart. • Parents who
are a member of a participating household. • Youth
ages 14 and older. • Foster parents, relative
caregivers, and unrelated court ordered caregivers.
Six files and twenty-two service plans were reviewed. Five of six files contained
services plans where signatures were late or missing.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
3

02/03/22 INTERIM, CAP approved 03/15/22
12/16/22 RENEWAL, CAP approved 01/04/23
FOM 801-03 Medical Passports
All medical information within the medical passport
must be current and updated at least quarterly to
reflect the child's current and complete health
information. n updated medical passport is provided
to: • Participating legal parents if the child is a
temporary court ward. Quarterly, while in out-of-
home placement. At reunification. Subsequent
medical passports are not required after
reunification. Non-offending parent, subsequent
medical passports are not required after
reunification.
Six foster care files were reviewed. One of six files documented that the last medical
passport update occurred on August 15, 2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Regarding R 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact. At the time
of the audit in January 2024 there was a case contact dated 11/28/23 that
documented that the youth was met with privately and a 901 Semi-annual
Meeting was referenced as occurring in the home on the same day. The 901
form documented that the youths medical and educational needs were
addressed however the contact should have noted that those needs were
addressed during the meeting. The contact also should have documented the
safety of the home and the youth’s feelings about the placement.
In two other files each one had a December 2023 contact that was not inputted
until January 2024. Contacts should be uploaded and ready for review at the time
of the audit.
 Regarding FOM 801-03 Medical Passports, signatures of foster parents on the
passport are not required quarterly, signatures are only required within two
weeks of the child’s admission into the home.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested or offered at this time.
4

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There was 1 substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. The agency initiated special evaluation #2023C0000925 on September 5,
2023. The agency established the following rule violations. R 400.9201 (1) (b), (e),
R 400.9403 (3), R 400.9404 (3), (4) (c), (e), R 400.9413 (1). The agency
recommended revocation of the license.
There was 1 incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. The agency initiated special evaluation #2023C0000925 on September 5,
2023. The agency established the following rule violations. R 400.9201 (1) (b), (e),
R 400.9403 (3), R 400.9404 (3), (4) (c), (e), R 400.9413 (1). The agency
recommended revocation of the license.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency submitted one corrective action plan during this period under review.
The agency submitted the corrective action plan on January 4, 2023, in response
to those violations established during the Renewal Inspection completed on
December 16, 2022. The current inspection established repeat violations for the
following rules and policies. R 400. 12418 (2) (b) Development of Service Plans, R
40012510 (2) Independent Living Agreement, FOM 722-06B Family Team
Meeting, and FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans. FOM 722-801-03 Medical
Passports, was a new violation established during the current inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrators annual assessment was reviewed. The assessment
detailed agency efforts to comply with their corrective action plan. The assessment
identified barriers that the agency encountered during the year which included
staff turnover and supervisors having to assume a caseload due to worker
vacancies.
Financial Overview
Agency financial records were submitted and reviewed with no noted concerns.
Staff Interviews
Staff interviewed reported that they enjoy working at the agency. They further
reported that they feel supported by their respective supervisor and their team.
Staff also reported that staff turnover has been a hardship for the team over the
past year.
Description of Agency Walk Through
CHRI documents were stored securely and no concerns were noted with the office
space.
5

VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The CPA Analyst did not identify any safety alerts during her visits to the homes.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
January 25, 2024
________________________________________
Douglas W Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
January 26, 2024

Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
